subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing
msgSnippet: ... I agree that we can improve things with the Template pattern, but I d need a template for JDBC, for JMS, ... for every different 3rd-party product I use.
messageBody:
Eugene Kuleshov wrote:

> It could be funny it it wouldn't be that sad. If all "complicated"
> would be like that we can get 200% test coverage...
>
> You came to the right conclusion that SQLException is an
> unrecoverable one and should be wrapped into a runtime exception. You
> even have slight improvement there with a common exception handler.
> There is only one step left before template pattern, so you can have
> exactly one place where that exception handler would be used. Take a
> look at JDBC packages in a Spring framework and either copy its design
> or use as is.
>
> Pretty much the same pattern can be applied to other common API's and
> many already in a very same Spring framework, so you won't have to
> invent the wheel.
>
> As I said, there are really good ways to make code more testable.

I agree that we can improve things with the Template pattern, but I'd
need a template for JDBC, for JMS, ... for every different 3rd-party
product I use. Even if I do that, I still need to test-drive the
template, or hide the template behind an interface so I can test-drive
the code that uses it. I suppose it is achievable, but I'm not sure it's
worth the effort.

If Java made the syntax for anonymous code blocks nicer, then I suppose
this wouldn't be a problem. What I find is that when I try to use the
Template pattern on projects, most of the people around me don't like it
or don't understand it, even though it's quite natural to me.
